advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR CONVENTION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Altair Convention was here announced in the Computer Notes magazine.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert tried to convince computers newcomers that a pocket computer could do the same as a desktop computer...<br><br><font color="#666666"> Now Texas Instruments brings you a cordless compact computer that solves the same sort of problems as the Apple or IBM Personal Computer...<br><br> ...For most personal computer tasks, its 6K RAM and 34K ROM are ample...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1985?)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Power 3000 released in the USA.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://hem.passagen.se/clab/adam/lambda/" target="_blank">Adam's Lambda 8300 page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first 1982 U.S. Advert.<br><br> Advert said <br><br>THE COMMODORE 64 COULD BE THE MICROCOMPUTER INDUSTRY'S OUTSTANDING NEW PRODUCT INTRODUCTION SINCE THE BIRTH OF THIS INDUSTRY. (Shearson / American Express) <br><br><font color="#666666"> The value of a computer is determined by what it can do. What it can do is largely determined by its memory.<br> The Commodore 64's basic RAM is 64K. This amount of power is unusual in a micro at any price.<br> At $595 it is astonishing.<br> Compared with an Apple II+, for instance, the Commodore 64 offers 33% more power and considerably les than 50% of the cost.<br> Compared with anything else, it's even more impressive...<br><br> If you've been waiting for the "computer revolution", consider it as having arrived... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>In the same magazine, Robert Hardling, the marketing manager of Atari Corporation said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> I envisage the situation where each house in 20 years time will have two, three or maybe more computers, ranging from a basic game machine through a home computer for education and home management and culminating in a fully fledged hyghly sophisticated computing work-station.<br> In the future, there may be only 3-4 major worldwide manufacturers. The IBM's, Apple's, Commodore's and Atari's of the world.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy is so good as running his budget that he has become rich and bought himself a TO-7/70 ! Or did he get rich since he bought its TO-7/70 ? Anyway he is now smoking cigars and reads stock market newspapers... great</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 5500 ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a french advert for the ISTC 5500 published in january 1981. Its is exactly the same advert used for the model 5000, apart some modification in the description (disk drive capacity). Even the picture is still the same, with a "5" added with a pen, by hand !!!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART</strong></font><br><blockquote>This document compares the different Panasonic systems of the serie<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Soichiro Oga</a> for this picture !</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUSTAR NETWORK</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar is the network version of the SuperBrain. Each SuperBrain computer became an 'intelligent' video terminal called a Video Processing Unit and containing its own microprocessor and 64 KB of RAM. Single or double floppy disc could be added for 350 KB to 1.5 MB local storage. Up to 255 terminals could be connected into the same network. Maximum cable length between two terminal was one mile at a 1.6 MB data transfer rate. Each of them could share a disk storage system, from 10 to 96 MB with CP/M operating system. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Choose from three computer systems:<br> The H-89 All-In-One Computer gives you everything in one compact, convenient unit.<br> The flexible H8 gives you the freedom to combine memory and interfacing for exactly the system you require.<br> And the powerful H11A gives you 16-bit power for your most complex programs.<br> The Heathkit line includes video terminals, matrix and letter quality printers, and accessories. You'll even find award-winning self-instruction packages to teach yourself programming in Basic or Assembly.</font></blockquote>

computer.description:
Like the MAX 20, the MAX 90 was derived from the AX 25, a computer designed by Axel, a small and innovative French company.
It was an almost PC-compatible system including some rare features at that time: 8 MHz 8088 processor, high resolution capability, and especially one or two 5.25" floppy disk drives of 2.7 MB capacity each. To our knowledge, it's the highest capacity ever seen for a 5.25" floppy drive unit.
A few thousand systems were sold to the French civil services, but this computer didn't become a success with private companies.
computer.graphics: 640 x 288 dots with an optional graphic card
computer.keyboard: Full stroke 92 keys with numeric keypad and arrow keys
computer.media: 2 x 5''1/4 disk-drives (2,7Mb each) or 1 x 5''1/4 disk-drive and 5 Mb hard disk
computer.name: MAX 90
computer.ports: Parallel, 2 x Serial, Game port, 5 x 8-bit ISA extension slots. Optional network and high resolution cards.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The keyboard was made in Japan, by Cherry.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><font color="blue">(1)</font> Reset button<br> <font color="blue">(2)</font> Serial/Modem connector<br> <font color="blue">(3)</font> Serial/Terminal connector<br> <font color="blue">(4)</font> Joystick connector<br> <font color="blue">(5)</font> Network connector from the optional network card<br> <font color="blue">(6)</font> Parallel printer connector<br> <font color="blue">(7)</font> Video connector. The connector also supplies the power to the monitor. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><font color="blue"><b>(1)</b></font> The keyboard comes from Cherry, in Japan<br> <font color="blue"><b>(2)</b></font> Two expansion cards are installed in this machine. The bottom one is a LAN card<br> <font color="blue"><b>(3)</b></font> The upper one is a 256 Kb RAM card<br> <font color="blue"><b>(4)</b></font> Fan<br> <font color="blue"><b>(5)</b></font> 65W switching power supply unit. Comes from Astek, Hong-Kong<br> <font color="blue"><b>(6)</b></font> Housing for dual 5.25" floppy drive units<br> <font color="blue"><b>(7)</b></font> Two holes allow the user to easily take off the upper part of the case.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The mainboard has a classic design with no custom chips. The majority of the components come from NEC.<br><br> <font color="blue"><b>(1)</b></font> This card supports 5 ISA slots. Extension cards are inserted horizontally.<br> <font color="blue"><b>(2)</b></font> Intel 8088 processor. A socket is available for an 8087 math coprocessor<br> <font color="blue"><b>(3)</b></font> 256 KB RAM chips in four banks of 64 KB (8 x 6164 chips + 1 parity chip). On this version, all the chips are soldered, some other versions of the board featured 128 KB of soldered chips and two additional banks of empty sockets for an optional 128 Kb of RAM<br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLOPPY DRIVES</strong></font><br><blockquote>The very high-capacity floppy drives (2.7 Mb) are labelled BASF, but these models were manufactured in Japan, by Canon</blockquote>
